paragraphs.text: Why Washington should fear the silence of the anti-war movement.
paragraphs.label: title

paragraphs.text: On this 73rd anniversary of the last declaration of war by the United States, as
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the Pentagon escalates its military actions in Iraq and Syria
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: the silence of the US peace movement carries an ominous warning for Washington, DC
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The streets of major US cities are not filled with anti-war demonstrations
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the apparent quiet does not signify consent
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: A look at history shows why
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The US has been attacked on domestic territory twice in the past century
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: On December 7, 1941, the Empire of Japan bombed Pearl Harbour
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: killing 2,403 Americans and wounding 1,178 others
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The next day, US Congress voted to declare war on Japan
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: thus committing to active hostilities in World War II
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: That declaration of war has since proved to be the last in the history of the US
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: The next and last mass scale violent attack by an outside aggressor on the domestic territory of the US occurred 13 years ago, on September 11, 2001, with the immediate death toll approaching 3,000
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: Three days later, Congress adopted an Authorisation for the Use of Military Force (AUMF) against those held responsible for the September 11 attacks
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: In so doing, Congress delegated war-making powers to President George W Bush under the terms of the War Powers Act of 1973
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: December 7 and September 11 are notable in part because in both cases horrendous violence against the people of the US was responded to with an act of Congress
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Oppose or support US entry into either of those wars, question or affirm that those wars were lawful, there was no question in either case that Congress had signed off on them
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Congressional approval
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: It mattered that Congress approve
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: because Article I, Section 8 of the US Constitution accords primary war powers, including the power to commence and end war, to Congress alone
paragraphs.label: common-ground

paragraphs.text: For a president of the US to make war without congressional approval was an unthinkable act that would have threatened the legitimacy of the federal government
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: With his war on the so-called Islamic State, US President Barack Obama has committed that unthinkable act
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: Congress has let him
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And yet
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: by all appearances, no one outside of a handful of members of Congress, legal scholars, and peace activists has spoken out in protest
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Contrast this moment with that of the weeks and months following September 11
paragraphs.label: other

paragraphs.text: On September 29, 2001, upwards of 25,000 people marched through Washington, DC, against the impending invasion of Afghanistan
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: tens of thousands demonstrated elsewhere throughout the US
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: By April 20, 2002, the anti-war protest in Washington drew over 150,000
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: By February 15, national protest turnout hit 2 million
paragraphs.label: statistics

paragraphs.text: Given this history, one cannot conclude that the size and volume of anti-war protests directly resulted from the relative popularity of a particular war
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: After all
paragraphs.label: no-unit

paragraphs.text: the 2001-2003 protests erupted and swelled over a period in which polls showed continued strong support among the US public for Washington's war operations
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: And in fact, as in 2003-2008 public opinion turned against the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, the size and volume of anti-war movement went down
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The simple and correct explanation for this history is that anti-war organisers made decisions in 2001, 2002, and 2003, to focus their energies on mobilising street protests
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: and that in the years 2004-2008, as anti-war sentiment was taken up by a majority of the American people, many anti-war organisers shifted much of their focus to electing anti-war candidates to office
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: What has changed since Obama assumed the presidency?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: In Washington, in terms of war and security, very little
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Guantanamo remains in operation
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: The police state has expanded
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Assassination and missile strikes have increased
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Border militarisation and deportations have escalated
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: And US military operations have continued and spread further across the globe
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Having lived and struggled through this history, why would anti-war organisers choose to respond to Washington's undeclared, unauthorised war against the so- called Islamic State by mobilising street protests?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Why would they mobilise to elect anti-war candidates?
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: The core of the peace movement remains active in many parts of the US
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Every day I receive notices about civil disobedience at military bases, hunger strikes, local government resolutions calling for a shift in spending priorities away from the military, and much more
paragraphs.label: anecdote

paragraphs.text: For this reason, the relative silence of anti-war organisers in the face of the war against the so-called Islamic State stands out as a warning to the Washington establishment; those who oppose their policies question whether Congress and the presidency can provide effective redress for the grievances of the American people
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: Washington should fear the silence of the US anti-war movement
paragraphs.label: assumption

paragraphs.text: for it is full of sound and fury and signifies everything
paragraphs.label: assumption
